title: Steve Hansen sent Eddie Jones text ahead of England vs New Zealand's Rugby World Cup semi-final
text:
New Zealand coach Steve Hansen has sent a text to England's Eddie Jones ahead of next week's Rugby World Cup semi-final showdown, offering to go for a drink after the match - no matter the score.

While the clash between two of the tournament favourites promises to be a heated affair as both sides scrap to reach the final in Yokohama, Hansen says there is no bad blood between he and Jones.

The 60-year-old Kiwi said he had made the goodwill gesture to the Australian because coaches 'go through the same emotions'.

New Zealand coach Steve Hansen says it is vital to keep a good relationship with other coaches

'I said, "Looking forward to seeing you and win, lose or draw we'll have a beer afterwards",' Hansen told the media.

'You see some of the banter which is really only to help promote the game as being, "Oh these guys don't like each other", which couldn't be further from the truth.'

He said it was important to remain a close relationship with his opposite numbers because 'the closer you are, the more you communicate'.

Hansen texted Eddie Jones with an offer to go for a drink after the sides contest the semi-final

Last week he spent time with Ireland defence coach Andy Farrell before his side ran out 46-14 winners against them.

'Coaches, regardless of whether you're playing against their team or not, go through the same emotions,' he added. 'You spend a lot of time in the same mental space. It's a game of footy, it's not life or death. The closer you are the more you communicate.

Hansen has steered the Kiwis to the Rugby World Cup semis after thrashing Ireland 46-14

England have bounced back from their 2015 World Cup disappointment under Eddie Jones

'It's like when you play against your brother or your sister, it's important, but it's not life-threatening.'

Hansen believes Jones is an inspirational figure because of his passion for Rugby. 'His passion, he loves the game,' he added.

'He's got a work ethic second to none – he put himself in hospital when he was here, he worked that hard. Anyone who loves the game will get my support.'
description: While the clash between two of the tournament favourites promises to be a heated affair as both sides scrap to reach the final in Yokohama, Hansen says there is no bad blood between he and Jones.
